description.narrative: Incubator staff Academic institutions including Universities and Colleges in the Gaza strip Students and fresh graduates from Business Administration, Engineering and IT Faculties in Universities and colleges Young and female potential entrepreneurs from marginalized groups Existing small sized companies and start-ups Stakeholders of "Business Development" and "Incubation" sectors and national policy makers

Project outcomes
Outcome 1.1: Improved performance for BTI on delivering higher quality support services for entrepreneurs by the end of 2014 Outcome 1.2: Offering better incubation facilities and services for incubated start-ups by the end of 2014 Measured improvement in BTI services as opposed to the baseline measurement in 2013 for its services,Improving services provided at BTI by 50% compared to a baseline measurement in 2013
Outcome 2.1: Incubated, 15 new start-ups, creating 1-3 jobs per start-up, and promoting entrepreneurship for youth and women among the public and society via conducting extensive TV coverage. (a) Number of start-ups created (a)Establishing 15 new start-up businesses (b) Number of jobs created(b)Creating at least 20 new jobs (c) Percentage of women in start-ups, (c) At least 40% of the start-up teams will include women entrepreneurs
Outcome 2.2: Accelerating 3 top start-ups providing them with advanced services, and sustaining 20 incubated start-ups till December, 2014 Number of products/services developed and offered by incubated start-ups. (a) Each of the 15 incubated start-ups will have at least one product/service approved and developed
Outcome 3.1: Graduated at least 25 highly skilled and motivated entrepreneurs who have professional business plans and increased employability by December, 2014
Outcome 3.2: Addressing and drafting a paper for removing business barriers for SMEs (a) Number of graduates who have entered a self-created or casual jobs within 6 months of courses completion (a) At least 3 start-ups will be registered by graduates within 12 months of courses completion, creating at least 6 new jobs (b) Number of start-ups created by graduates (b) At least 40% of the graduates from the courses will have landed on a job within 12 months after graduation (c) Number of barriers addressed (c) Addressing registration barrier for SMEs in Gaza strip
Project outputs Output 1.1.1: BTI has a full strategic plan in place and documents its progress using a Balanced-score card BSC model by December, 2014 Number and details of strategic plan components Number of indicators in the BSC,Finalizing the plan by May, 2014 and monitoring progress against the BSC until Dec, 2014
Output 1.1.2: BTI team members received training on at least 3 professional business incubation modules by welcoming experts to Gaza and attending training sessions and seminars abroad by August, 2014 Number of training modules successfully finished,Finishing at least 3 training modules (Advanced and InfoDev module)
Output 1.2.1: Increasing BTI's capacity by Preparing about 15 additional incubation units and common space for meetings with video conferencing tools and other equipments by August, 2014 Output 1.2.2: Preparing a small ICT lab for web development and mobile applications by November, 2014 Number of units prepared,Preparing 15 additional units Number and type of devices equipped for the computer lab,Preparing a lab with 5 PCs and 10 mobile devices
Output 2.1.1: Training and coaching 200 participants on shaping their business ideas and pitches by April, 2014 Output 2.1.2: Training and coaching 80 potential entrepreneurs from 40 groups by professional experts on developing their business, finance and marketing plans by June, 2014 Output 2.1.3: Training 60 incubated entrepreneurs from 30 incubated start-up on professional pitches by July, 2014 Number of participants trained and number of training hoursTraining 200 individuals for 18 hours each + Coaching them to develop their product
* Degree of satisfaction on training subjects, Training 80 potential entrepreneurs for 36 hours+ Coaching them to develop their business plans
Number of Business Plans initially approved : Training 60 incubated entrepreneurs for 9 hours on pitching
Increase training and coaching satisfaction rate by 10% over the same measured period in 2013
Output 2.1.4: Incubating additional 15 new start-ups and supporting them with incubation services by August, 2014.
Output 2.1.4: Incubating additional 15 new start-ups and supporting them with incubation services by August, 2014.
Output 2.2.1: Providing a public match-making service for incubated start-ups having them to pitch on the TV, reaching local and regional audiences of potential investors and customers Output 2.2.2: Selecting and supporting 3 high-potential start-ups by December, 2014.
Number of start-ups incubated and awarded prize Incubating 15 new start-ups resulting in about 40 incubated start-ups overall for 3 months Number of start-ups accelerated after incubationaccelerating 3 top startups and sustaining incubation for the top 20 Number of Coaching hours provided for incubated start-upsProviding 15 hours of coaching for each incubated startup
Output 3.1.1: Implementing a one-year Entrepreneurship Professional Diploma program with training/lectures and field work
Output 3.1.2: graduating at least 25 highly skilled entrepreneurs who are able to start their businesses
Number of graduated participants25 participants will have successfully completed the course and received certifications
- Number of training/lecture hours provided delivering at least 140 hours of lectures and field training Number of business plans created by participants;At least 20 participants will have developed their own professional business plans
Output 3.2.1: Holding sessions and meetings addressing start-up barriers, namely in registration, and recommending solutions for proper authorities to take action : Number of meetings and round-table workshops held for policy making:Holding 1 roundtable sessions and 5 meetings with stakeholders on the subject

This project aims to reduce poverty and unemployment among young entrepreneurs through encouraging them to start their own sustainable businesses by transforming the innovative ideas of the entrepreneurs in Gaza strip into small businesses and projects through providing integrated packages of business development professional services and offering means of linking and matchmaking with the external markets and businesses, which will enhance the economic situation, reduce unemployment, create new sustainable jobs, products and services. The program also is aimed to build strategic linkages between business development programs, local and international businesses and firms along with the academic institutions.
The CIA World Fact book, accessed on 11 Dec, 2011 Ministry of Planning and administrative development , The Palestinian National Millennium Development Goals Progress Report- Sep. 2010 World Bank (2008) Palestinian Economic Prospects: Aid, Access and Reform, Sep. 2008
